page.title: 02Battle of Bossenden Wood.
page.content: In the south west corner of the area bordering on farmlands, lies Bossenden (pronounced 'Bozenden') Wood, on the edge of the Blean. This was the scene of the last occasion when the army was brought in to put down civil unrest in England. In 1838, John Tom, a young Cornishman, calling himself Sir William Courtenay, set up as a Messiah, urging the local labouring men to rise 'for the rights of the poor' against their masters. Having killed the constable sent to arrest him, Courtenay spent the night at Bossenden Farm, and the following morning he and his small band of loyal followers faced a detachment of Infantry and in the 'battle' that followed, lost his life. The site of the battle, never very obvious, is now totally obscured, but the name remains as a landmark in local history.
